texts.definition: A measure of how much damage or other negative consequences avatars, characters, or units can take before they suffer serious penalties.
markups: <style="Definition">A measure of how much damage or other negative consequences avatars, characters, or units can take before they suffer serious penalties.</style>

When damage in games does not directly lead to death or elimination, this still has to have some effect for the damage to have a gameplay purpose. The most common solution to this is most likely having a <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> attribute. While each time damage is taken can have individual effects, reducing <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> completely or beyond certain levels can have additional effects.

<style="CurrentLink">Health</style> has been examined by several other collections of game design elements under the name "Hit Points", e.g. Giant Bomb, TVTropes, and the RPG Design Patterns collection. For more information, see also the entries for <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> on Wikipedia and Giant Bomb.

Many Roleplaying Games, e.g. Dungeons & Dragons, GURPS, the Dragon Age series, the Fallout series make use of "hit points" to keep track of players' Health. The Legend of Zelda series and Minecraft instead use hearts to indicate how healthy the players' characters are. Fighting Games such as the Mortal Combat and Tekken series make use of "hit points" in similar style. The Board Games Ghost Stories and Talisman keep track of Health through tokens (although Ghost Stories call them "Qi" tokens).

Being hit or falling in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike%20series">Counter-Strike series</link></style> or the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%20series">Team Fortress series</link></style> reduces <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> which is displayed as a bar in the user interfaces. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Grand%20Theft%20Auto%20series">Grand Theft Auto series</link></style> complement <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> values with armor values which reduced damage but are themselves reduced when doing so. While these relate to the same type of damage that can happen the games; ones based upon the stories of H.P. Lovecraft, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Arkham%20Horror">Arkham Horror</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mansions%20of%20Madness">Mansions of Madness</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Call%20of%20Cthulhu">Call of Cthulhu</link></style> often have both physical and mental <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> values.

The number of members in squads in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Memoir%20'44">Memoir '44</link></style> is a form of <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> value since individual losses do not reduce the effectiveness of them - first when all members have been eliminated is there any effect and that is the complete removal of the squad.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/H%C3%A2rnmaster">Hârnmaster</link></style>, a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Game</link></style>, avoids using <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> by instead have numerical values of how penalizing each wound is and aggregating these to provide a penalty for character actions. Checks for unconsciousness and deaths are determined when the wound is received.

<style="CurrentLink">Health</style> is basically an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attribute</link></style> which sometimes can be used as a <style="Link"><link="resources">Resource</link></style>, so designing games to make use of <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> to a large extent consist of considering the design options of these two other patterns. While <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> are natural choices of game elements to have <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> attributes, the pattern is also often used with <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> and sometimes with <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style> as well.

A design decision needed regarding <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> is if they are an independent <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attribute</link></style> or based on some other <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attribute</link></style>; <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> for example bases it on "Strength" but lets it be modified in different ways while <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pendragon">Pendragon</link></style> instead lets it equal a <style="Link"><link="characters">Character's</link></style> "Constitution" plus "Size". An alternative to using <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> as a separate <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attribute</link></style> is to let <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> affect another <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attribute</link></style> instead. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mutant:%20%C3%85r%20Noll">Mutant: År Noll</link></style> does this with all <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style> to indicate <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> cause not only by physical trauma but also stress, confusion, and doubt.

Health is sometimes split into several different Attributes. Quake, for example, has both health and armor Attributes which have very similar properties. Call of Cthulhu and Arkham Horror show that one can make distinction between mental and physical Health.

The <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> and <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> patterns often influence each other heavily, but <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> modifies <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> since the latter one can exist without the former and used together they create <style="Link"><link="energy-penalties">Energy Penalties</link></style>. While <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> causes reductions in <style="CurrentLink">Health</style>, there are many ways of modifying this. <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style> can reduce the amount of <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> taken and acquiring them, or choosing which one to use, can become gameplay elements. <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerabilities</link></style> can make some types of attacks ineffective while <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style> can instead make some types of attacks much more dangerous. <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="handicap-systems">Handicap Systems</link></style> can be applied before or during game instances to shift gameplay between <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging</link></style> and to try to find <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="team-balance">Team Balance</link></style>.

While complete reduction of the <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> due to <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> typically leads to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20Element%20Removal">Game Element Removal</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="player-killing">Player Killing</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Elimination</link></style>, the use of <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> can add granularity to this by introducing additional levels where other effects take place. One example of this can be found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>: falling below one third of one's <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> halves <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>, losing all requires <style="Link"><link="dice">Die</link></style> rolls every second to stay conscious, and receiving <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> double to one's <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> requires rolls to avoid death. These effects are in addition to specific ones caused by the <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> that reduced the <style="CurrentLink">Health</style>.

If <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> can be healed or repaired, it becomes a <style="Link"><link="renewable-resources">Renewable Resource</link></style> and a <style="Link"><link="regenerating-resources">Regenerating Resource</link></style> if this happens automatically. <style="Link"><link="chargers">Chargers</link></style> are <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> that can provide this effect, and together with healing <style="Link"><link="pick-ups">Pick-Ups</link></style> show how restoring <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> can be linked to moving in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. Being able to perform healing actions is a way players to affect <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> actively, and can be made possible through <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style>; how well they can do this can be modulated through <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>. Such abilities make candidates for being <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>.

Given the importance of <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> values for overall gameplay development, they are usually displayed as <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style> so they are easily noticeable by players. For their own <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, this may be through <style="Link"><link="hud-interfaces">HUD Interfaces</link></style> since these <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> may not be visible themselves to players. <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widgets</link></style> - for example hovering health bars - are often used for players' own <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>, encountered <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, or the <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="teams">Team</link></style> members. The <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> of <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> may also be shown as <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widgets</link></style> but for added complexity the <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> of them may only be shown if players investigate them, e.g. by aiming at them with <style="Link"><link="crosshairs">Crosshairs</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Health</style> is an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attribute</link></style> which in many cases functions as a (<style="Link"><link="non-localized-resources">Non-Localized</link></style>) <style="Link"><link="resources">Resource</link></style> since it often is depleted during gameplay - if healing abilities exist this is even more likely since it can then be treated as a <style="Link"><link="renewable-resources">Renewable Resources</link></style>. It allows higher granularity in <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> by letting <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> have accumulative effects; by doing this it can also introduce intermittent states between the loss of <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style>. The use of <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> reductions as <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> can become <style="Link"><link="critical-hits">Critical Hits</link></style> when combined with additional effects such as <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Disruption%20of%20Focused%20Attention">Disruption of Focused Attention</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="variable-accuracy">Variable Accuracy</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="movement-limitations">Movement Limitations</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style>.

Given that <style="CurrentLink">Health</style> is an abstract <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attribute</link></style> on can arguably claim that adding this through <style="Link"><link="hud-interfaces">HUD Interface</link></style> can be enough for an otherwise <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Avatar">Avatar</link></style>-based game to support a weak form of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>.
